job_title: Patient Observation in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: - Choose your own schedule - Only required to work 2 weekend days in a pay period - Doesn't require a degree - Don't have the responsibilities that techs and nurses have (physical hands on jobs) - Go with patients to various testing and procedures - Have the experience to learn from watching doctors, nurses, techs, x-ray, etc. - Get sent to various units - Learn how to work with different types of patients (Alzheimers, Psyche, Alcohol Withdrawl, etc.) - May get flexed or go home early after patient is discharged
cons: - Lack of training - Must work with difficult staff and patients - Not have training how to deal with types of patients (Agitated, confused, psyche, violent, etc) - Some nurses/techs expect you to know how to calm a patient down and do their job - Not get breaks or lunch/dinner - Boring days sometimes - Work with patients that speak other languages - Work with patients that may be violent or extremely agitated/confused - Not get treated fairly by patients and some staff - Must have a lot of patience and a cool temper - Cannot leave room - Must deal with difficult/abusive family members - Cannot leave room to cool down - May be screamed at, kicked, spit on, punched, hit, or threatened by patients - Get forgotten by staff - Cannot leave on time, must wait for relief which may come 30 min-1 hour late... - May be asked but not required to work a double - Work weekends and holidays as required (with time and a half pay) Per Diems may get flexed - Long days (Morning shift 7-am-3/3:30pm, Evening shift (3pm-11pm, Night shift 11pm-7am) - May be sent to answer phones on unit without training (May be asked by patients calling in to transfer to their nurse without knowing who or extension, will answer calls from other units and staff without knowing who to transfer, difficult to track down someone for help, not know how to direct patients and family members when asked, not know how to assist other staff members or direct them, everyone assumes you're a secretary even if you tell them you're not, people get frustrated with you despite not having training or being a secretary, stare at the wall and wait for a phone call or time to go home.)

job_title: Nurse in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Saint Peter's Healthcare System's, Adult Health Center How Lane is a very good company to work for. It is a fast paced working environment where our nursing and clinical assistant PCT staff get along very well together. We are a family. One of the reasons why I enjoy working here is because the management team listens and respects my opinion. This makes me feel valued as an employee. Many of the staff members have been working here for 5, 10, 20 and even 30 years, supporting each other. We cover for each other at the drop of a hat. When one of us is out sick or on vacation, patients ask for us by name. We became nurses because we love to care for our patients. A few of us have worked in this practice until retirement. This shows that How Lane Adult Center is a wonderful place to work.
cons: We have no control over staff calling out sick.

review_title: Valuable because of its nurses, but does not value them
job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
You work alongside some good people (nurses, techs). Depending on who your manager is, you might work in a unit where your manager makes you feel supported. Patients have repeatedly said the care they receive at Saint Peter's is excellent, often comparing it favorably to other hospitals. Parking is free if you have your badge.
Opportunities to advance are probably plentiful, because nobody wants to stay.
Differential for certification is higher than other places.
cons:
Physician/Resident caliber is pretty low; bottom-of-the-barrel in most specialties except maybe NICU/Maternity-related. Knowledgeable nurses are appalled by how non-proactive so many of the attendings are in addressing time-sensitive issues. Despite it being against policy, many attendings won't bother putting orders in and will spend twenty minutes fighting with the nurse to have the put the orders in rather than just doing what they're supposed to do, and there does not seem to be consequences to them. In light of the Radonda verdict, this is especially appalling. With a few notable exceptions, the majority of the residents do not have a sense of responsibility, follow-up, or even accountability for basic information they should know. As a new nurse if I have to consistently remind you that an order is inappropriate for your patient, you should be ashamed. 
Administrators are not supportive of nursing staff; nursing educators, higher-level nursing administrators just want their metrics to improve by squeezing more out of the nurses doing all the work instead of doing more to support them,
The charting system is nominally better than messenger pigeon. In order to properly care for your patient with the limited resourcing available and to document everything properly, you regularly stay very late. With more agency nurses, we are able to compare notes on what things are like at different hospitals. It's apparently not like this everywhere; our system is truly the worst.

job_title: Patient Observer in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
-If you're in college and need a part time job
 -Looking to see if you'll like the healthcare field
-I enjoyed my co-workers and sometimes the chaos I had to go through was funny.It really depends on the unit and shift you work.
-It's a paycheck
-The experience will help you get a new job when it's time to move on(I was only unemployed a few weeks after I quit)
-Other staff members will give you tips on how to do your job better(a charge nurse showed me how to document properly.My manager was the one who should have done that.)
-I met some amazing people who taught me so much,made me laugh on the worst shifts and protected me as much as they could.They're all beautiful people and I'm so glad to have known them.
cons:
-The current manager is an issue but you'll be ok if you keep to yourself.Just don't talk about anything personal.Be polite and professional. She did very little to make me and other observers feel safe before the pandemic. It was the patient's safety before our own.The issue became worse during the first wave on the pandemic. We were not allowed to have anything more than a surgical mask but were still assigned covid patients(you don't go into the rooms,she told us). She promised in the beginning we wouldn't have any.That changed quickly. Then it was only"droplet precautions".Once she told me I would have "airborne precaution" patients,I gave her my two weeks notice. I already felt stressed worrying about my co-workers and that was the last straw. Please always remember,you have the right to not only feel safe but be safe. Protect your patient and your co-workers as best you can but don't harm yourself in the process.
-Inconsistent training. I was shown a 30 minute video on how to properly feed a patient and no other training. Another observer was prepped fully. 
-Depending on the shift and unit,you'll probably be on your own. Just do your best.Press the call bell and yell out for help. Don't let yourself get hurt because other staff members refuse to help.You're there to "observe". However if the nurse or aide asks for something reasonable like cleaning the patient's face while they're washing the rest of them,there is nothing wrong with that. Do what makes you feel comfortable and within reason but keep yourself safe.
-You will have patients that should not be with you. If you don't feel safe with a patient,speak up.Your safety is number 1 before the patient.Don't let anyone ever tell you otherwise.Always cover yourself. If the patient fell make sure you write down if you intervened in order to prevent their fall and if you couldn't,write why. I had a patient trying to punch me in the face and they fell but I was able to make sure they didn't hit their head. With a patient fall,some people are looking to place the blame on someone. Document properly. Do your job to the best of your ability. 
-Very stressful when the patient is very bad.Again it's your job to observe and not be a human punching bag. Ask to be moved if the patient is harassing you.You don't deserve to deal with that for 8 hours.

job_title: Staff RN in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Lots of vacation and holiday time that you can use whenever you want as long as you have hours.  Self scheduling , no rotating weekends! You are required to work 3 weekend days a month but it's your decision when. Team work is evident in each unit. Awards and recognition are given to well deserve individuals.
cons: Low entry-level pay, only place that does new graduate internship or trains no hospital experience RNs without hiring or paying them for 3 months!  Also raise is based on your evaluation by nurse manager, if you are a suck up expect 5%-6% raise. If you do your job properly and mind your own business without small talk and gossip you get nothing ☹️. Worst charting system, very slow, redundant and not user friendly.

review_title: Working here is GREAT as long as you do not work for one of their satellite locations.

review_title: Saint Peter's University Hospital has an outstanding culture.
job_title: Registered Nurse
pros: Saint Peter's University Hospital continually goes above and beyond for both their employees and the patients that they serve. They take their mission statement very seriously and implement  that mission in all that they do. They are very supportive and continually acknowledge hard work.
cons: There are no cons to working at Saint Peter's University Hospital. However, because we are a smaller organization than other area hospitals , I believe the community may not recognize our value. It is not the size of the organization that represents it's value, rather, it is the people that make up the organization.

review_title: A company thriving in a difficult health care market
job_title: Care Coordination in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Saint Peters University Hospital continues to be a vibrant part of the central New Jersey health care options.  Like a David in a land of giants, St Peters, a relatively small health care system, competes with Robert Wood Johnson, Meridian, Barnabas in the central Jersey market as a vibrant option in the area.  St Peters UH is a Magnet Hospital for five consecutive times and hold many other significant awards and accolades.
cons: There has been a rotation of top level management in the past  few years which always brings a sense of instability to the culture with every change.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
- Nice area of the city to work in
- Clean and Safe work environment
- Free parking for employees 
- Salary was reasonable
cons:
- HR and upper management do not have clear guidelines/policies in place to prevent ALL types of harassment, bullying, and intimidation within the workplace
- Hospital politics cripple and prevent certain departments (specifically the department of surgery) within the organization from firing those people in "management" who are unfit, unqualified, and uneducated to perform basic job duties or be a professional team leader
- Unprofessional, hostile, and intimidating work environments have lead to very low morale and high turnover rates within the department of Surgery (I am the second residency program coordinator to leave that position within less then a year) .  There is a constant sense of anxiety and fear that the work you are performing isn't "good enough"
- For anybody who's looking to advance within the healthcare administration field, there are no real opportunities for professional growth because certain departments do not have the right leaders to assist with this
- Micromanagement  will inevitably prevent you from being able to perform the job you were qualified to be hired for 
- No type of structured training programs for new employees (in the department of surgery) due to the office coordinator/managers lack of knowledge/qualifications

job_title: in New Brunswick, NJ
